Situation1: Going to the gym to maintain physical fitness
Expectation2: Teach Torah and Jewish law to children and adults.
Situation2: An optional, drop-in adult education class on a general topic is scheduled.
Story:
I laced up my sneakers, ready for my usual hour at the gym. As a police officer, keeping fit isn’t just about looking the part—it’s about being able to protect people when it matters. My shift had been long, but I knew I needed this time to stay sharp, to be the officer my community expects. Just as I grabbed my water bottle, my phone buzzed. It was a reminder about the adult education class at the synagogue. I was supposed to lead a discussion on ethics in the Torah, a session I’d scheduled as an optional drop-in for anyone interested. 

I pictured the handful of regulars who might show up, waiting for guidance, for a word of wisdom. As their rabbi, I’m meant to be present, to teach, to nurture their spiritual growth. But I also knew that skipping my workout meant letting my physical readiness slip, risking my ability to serve and protect. The weight of both uniforms pressed on me—one demanding strength of body, the other strength of spirit. I stood in the hallway, keys in hand, torn between the gym and the synagogue, feeling the pull of both callings and the impossibility of being fully present in both at once.
